Hi Felix,

This is an interesting question, and I don't think it's been bro=
ught up here
before.

In my experience, this is a bit hard to quantify, but=
 it's probably fair to
say that while the cost appears a bit on the high si=
de initially (especially
if the developers on your team are not used to wri=
ting tests and that there
is no existing testing infrastructure), it tends =
to decrease over time as
programmers become more experienced in writing tes=
ts, reuse or create test
base classes and tend to write solid tests in thei=
r first iteration.

Although it's obviously hard to prove or disprove, I wo=
uld probably say that
at the very beginning, it's not rare to spend as much=
 time writing a test as
it is to implement the corresponding feature.  That=
 first test is always
very expensive, especially if it's an area of your pr=
oduct that has no tests
at all.  It all gets better after that.

Hope it he=
lps, and looking forward to other people's answers.
